III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Alleged sexual contact between unidentified youths implying
inadequate supervision.
Investigation Interviews:
I left a voice message for Complainant on 4/1/24 and received a
call back on 4/2/24 identifying Youth A as the source of the
allegations.
I contacted Youth A’s Foster Care Worker and notified her of the
investigation assignment. She had no additional licensing
concerns to report.
INCIDENT 1:
I interviewed Youth A on 4/2/24 at school. He said he was
admitted to Wolverine Center on 3/6/24 and has had multiple
other placements. Youth A described one incident on an unknown
date where he said Former Youth J touched his “backside and
hips.” He said this occurred in the community bathroom while
Staff 1 was monitoring both youths at the bathroom door. Youth A
said Staff 1 guided Former Youth J out of the bathroom when he
heard Youth A cursing at Former Youth J.
Former Youth J is cognitively impaired and was discharged to his
mother’s home in March 2024.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the school. He has worked at the facility
for two months. Staff 1 recalled Youth A was showering, and
Former Youth J asked to go in and use the toilet. “I let him use
the bathroom.” Staff 1 stood at the bathroom door and heard
Youth J washing his hands. He momentarily turned his attention
to another youth outside the bathroom. “I heard Youth A ask,
2

‘What are you doing?’ I told Former Youth J to leave out and he
left on his own. Afterward, Youth A seemed upset and told me
Former Youth J was looking at him…I did not see Former Youth J
touch Youth A sexually.”
INCIDENT 2
Youth A noted a second incident on 4/1/24 where Youth E tried to
enter his room and threatened to “fuck and rape” him. “Staff 2
stopped him.”
I interviewed Youth E on 4/2/24 at the facility. He is placed in the
short-term shelter program and had only been there for four days.
Youth E denied threatening to sexually assault Youth A.
Staff 2’s employment was terminated on 4/12/24. I attempted to
interview him by phone on 4/21/24 but his number was out of
service.
Video:
Video of the second-floor hallway on 4/1/24 shows Staff 2
supervising the hallway.
Analysis It cannot be determined if Former Youth J touched Youth A’s hips
and backside in the bathroom. However, both Youth A and Staff 1
said Staff 1 was at the bathroom door supervising.
It cannot be determined if Youth E verbally threatened to rape
Youth A on 4/1/24. However, Youth A reported, and video footage
confirmed that staff were supervising the area when the alleged
threat occurred.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Facility and premises maintenance
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4407
Section (3) The facility, including main and accessory structures, shall be
Description maintained so as to prevent and eliminate rodent and insect
harborage.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
3

Allegation Allegedly there are bugs and cockroaches in building and mice in
basement.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A said on 3/9/24 he found a dead mouse in the basement
bathroom, flushed it down the toilet and informed an unidentified
staff. He has also seen ants in the basement and on the main
floor.
Youth E said he has not noticed any bugs, mice or cockroaches in
the building.
Tour Observation:
I observed the basement on 3/28/24 and did not see any mice or
insects.
Consultant 2 toured the building on 3/28/24 and also did not see
any mice or insects.
Documents reviewed:
An Interim Inspection Report dated 7/31/23 indicates the facility
passed an environmental health inspection on 7/28/23 with an A
rating.
I reviewed Orkin receipts for services rendered. On 2/17/24, the
building was treated for bedbugs and billed $8500. On 3/6/24,
standard monthly insecticides were applied for a charge of $95.99.
Analysis When the building was toured on 3/28/24 there was not any
evidence of an insect or mice infestation. Documentation shows
Wolverine Center has an exterminator who applies insecticides on
a monthly basis.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
